comment._content: February 7, 1916: R. Lindley Murray gave another demonstration of his brilliant tennis play on the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon when he triumphed without difficulty over Dr. A.W. Waite, the senior metropolitan indoor champion, in the fourth round of the national indoor singles championship. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20613FC345C13738...

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Dr. Arthur Warren Waite, a dentist and well kown as tennis player. In March 1916, he poisoned his father-in-law, John E. Peck, a millionnaire drug manufacturer of Grand Rapids, Mich., see The Day book., March 25, 1916, LAST EDITION, Image 7, with photo Omaha daily bee., March 30, 1916, Page 2, with photo Keowee courier., March 29, 1916, Image 3, col. 3 Later it was revealed that he had murdered his mother-in-law as well. The case is described in murderpedia.org/male.W/w/waite-arthur-warren.htm and www.executedtoday.com/2008/05/24/1917-dr-arthur-waite-pla... Mrs. John E. Peck (Hannah Peck):

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: This photo is showing the brother-in-law (Percy Peck) of A. W. Waite. I could not find a photo of the murdered John Peck, the father-in-law, in the Bain Collection. A photo of John Peck in the newspapers is e.g. in The Democratic banner., March 28, 1916, Image 1.
